mvp.listener

Class AbstractListenerDialog

  • java.lang.Object
    • mvp.listener.AbstractListenerDialog
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.util.EventListener, ListenerDialog, ListenerView

    public abstract class AbstractListenerDialog
extends java.lang.Object
implements ListenerDialog
    An abstract implementation of ListenerDialog that mirrors the AbstractListenerView class. The main difference between the two is that this class does not also implement the PropertyChangeView interface, as dialogs have a short lifespan and in general won't persist long enough to need to receive PropertyChangeEvents. If a unique case arises where such functionality would be necessary, that interface can still be implemented by a subclass of this.

    Like AbstractListenerView, this class has been implemented to accept multiple external ActionListeners and store them in a list. This class also implements actionPerformed(ActionEvent) inherited from ActionListener as a final method. This implementation simply creates a new ActionEvent with the same action command as the one that was passed to it, but with this class as the event's source. This allows for the external listening controller(s) to abstractly access this class, and the getValueForAction(String) method specifically.

    The getValueForAction(String) method inherited from the ListenerView interface will also need to be implemented by subclasses. The documentation for ListenerView should be consulted for the best way to implement this method.

    NOTE: A view extending this class cannot also extend a GUI component class, so views using this API will have to rely on composition (wrapping around an instance of the GUI component their building) rather than inheritence to create components.

    NOTE: External listeners to receive ActionEvents should be added to instances of ListenerDialog before the showDialog() method is invoked. For maximum flexibility, AbstractListenerView has been designed to also serve as a listener for dialogs implementing this interface, in case the dialog is created within a GUI class and can't add the controller directly as an ActionListener. If AbstractListenerView receives an ActionEvent from this dialog, it will safely pass it along to the controller without changing its source.

    THREAD SAFETY: Swing is NOT thread safe. All methods in this class MUST be invoked on the EventDispatchThread.

    Version:
    2.0
    Author:
    craig
    See Also:
    AbstractListenerView

        public void addActionListener(java.awt.event.ActionListener listener)
